Award.AwardTitle: RUI: Parameter Estimation, Data Analysis, and Detector Characterization for LIGO
Award.AbstractNarration:
The observation of gravitational waves by the Laser Interferometer Gravitational-wave Observatory (LIGO) will be a tremendous scientific accomplishment, but the resources provided through this grant will create many other positive opportunities. Carleton College is a leader in producing future scientists. This project will provide research opportunities to students with interests in physics and statistics, and help train them to become the next generation of scientists. Carleton students are eager to participate in exciting research, and their interest in gravitational wave astronomy, and science in general, is large. The computational statistical methods developed as a consequence of this project have, and will continue to have significant influence in other scientific fields: astrophysics, chaos studies, and gravitational wave detectors in space. The project will also continue to provide material that will improve teaching at the college level; subjects that will benefit from the science covered in this project include optics, general relativity, and statistics. This project also creates opportunities for scientific outreach; high school students and high school teachers will continue to be exposed to the wonder and significance of LIGO's research, and this outreach creates much excitement for science and physics. Finally, the research work of this project promotes international scientific collaboration. Albert Einstein predicted the existence of gravitational waves in 1916; a century later we should actually observe gravitational waves, and consequently the scientific and educational benefit will be tremendous.

Events seen by LIGO will produce a wealth of astrophysical information, the extraction of which will require advanced techniques in data analysis, parameter estimation, and statistics. Detector characterization work will provide scientists with confidence in the quality of the data, and the performance of the detectors. Carleton College will continue with its significant efforts in identifying and characterizing noise in LIGO data; this information will be fed back to the interferometer operators in order to improve the detector performance. Carleton and colleagues are researching how to eliminate magnetic field noise from the Schumann resonances that is coherent in the LIGO-Virgo detector network. Carleton will use LIGO data to observe a cosmologically produced stochastic gravitational wave background. Carleton will contribute to the effort to detect long duration gravitational waves by correlating data from two detectors, and using pattern recognition techniques to look for signals. The Carleton team will develop Bayesian parameter estimation methods to extract physical parameters associated with core collapse supernova produced gravitational wave signals.

POR.DRECONTENT:
This grant from the National Science Foundation,
RUI: Parameter Estimation, Data Analysis, and Detector Characterization for LIGO,
to Carleton College, has provided resources for a professor and his students to conduct significant gravitational wave science and research with the Laser Interferometer Gravitational-wave Observatory (LIGO).

The Carleton team spent much time studying the quality to the LIGO data in order to identify noise that could adversely affect a search for gravitational wave signals. In some cases, these results were used to discard data that was clearly of poor quality. It was also used to help identify the source of the noise so it could be fixed at the LIGO sites. Normally it is assumed that the noise at the two LIGO sites are independent of one another since they are separated by 3000 km. However the Carleton team helped to show that a type of magnetic noise that bounces around the Earth can cause correlated magnetic noise. Methods were developed to subtract this magnetic noise once it truly affects the LIGO data.

For many years the team at Carleton College has developed methods to analyze gravitational wave data in such as way as to extract the physical parameters associated with the signal. For example, to estimate the masses of the two objects when they orbit and merger together. Where the events are on the sky, or how far away they, can be estimated as well. Now that ten gravitational wave signals from the mergers of binary black hole systems, and the gravitational wave signal from a binary neutron star merger, have been observed, these parameter estimation methods are used to tell the full story about the amazing astrophysical events that created these signals.

The Carleton College team works closely with the team from NASA's Fermi Gamma-ray Burst Monitor (Fermi-GBM). The coincident observation of gravitational waves from the binary neutron star merger GW170817, along with gamma rays from this event GRB 170817A, shows how much astrophysical and cosmological information can be extracted from these coincident observations. The Carleton team, including undergraduates, have been at the front-lines of this scientific effort between LIGO and Fermi-GBM.

Carleton College also participates in the effort by LIGO to observe a stochastic background of gravitational waves. These waves could be produced, for example, in the creation of the Universe, the Big Bang, and permeate all points of space today. While no stochastic background has been detected, important limits on its intensity have been set. From the observations of gravitational waves from binary black hole and binary neutron star mergers we have predicted that in the coming years LIGO should be able to detect a stochastic background produced by these sorts of events over the history of the universe.

Probably the most important outcome of this grant has been the amazing research opportunities that it has created for Carleton College undergraduates. Because of these research projects the students have been trained in exciting and important scientific research, and have gone onto some of the best graduate schools in the United States. The educational benefits provided by this grant have been outstanding. This has helped to train the next generation of successful scientists.
